items.title: City Setting, but Village Mentalities
items.abstract: The protest movement that has sprung up in Delhi after a brutal rape in December is largely a lament of the city against a nation that has blamed attacks on women on the women's own modernity.

items.title: Together a Century, City and Oil Giant Hit a Rough Patch
items.abstract: Chevron has spent millions in recent years trying to shore up its relationship with Richmond, Calif., but many residents still oppose the company’s efforts to repair a refinery hit by a fire.

items.title: Schools of Design Extend Their Reach Into Asia
items.abstract: While the potential for growth is huge, given Asia’s rising creative industries, the logistics of opening American art and design schools can be complicated.
keywords: Savannah College of Art and Design

items.title: Ada Louise Huxtable, Champion of Livable Architecture, Dies at 91
items.abstract: Ms. Huxtable pioneered modern architectural criticism in The New York Times, celebrating buildings that respected human dignity and civic history.

items.title: Nashville’s Latest Big Hit Could Be the City Itself
items.abstract: The city, which sat on the sidelines while its Southern sisters boomed, has found itself in the national spotlight, with economic gains and a newly found popularity.

items.title: In Israeli City of Haifa, a Liberal Arab Culture Blossoms
items.abstract: The embrace of secularism, feminism and gay rights in the cafes and bars of this cosmopolitan city is creating a counterpoint to Israeli Arabs’ traditional conservatism.

items.title: ‘Design Thinking’ for a Better You
items.abstract: A strategy called “design thinking” has helped numerous entrepreneurs and engineers develop successful new products and businesses. But can design thinking help you create healthful habits?

items.title: Intimate, Haunting Portraits of New York City Youth
items.abstract: The photographer (and model) Ethan James Green finds many of the subjects in his ongoing series of creatives on social media.

items.title: New York City
items.abstract: New books include Gerard Koeppel’s “City on a Grid: How New York Became New York.”
keywords: City on a Grid: How New York Became New York (Book)
Fun City: John Lindsay, Joe Namath, and How Sports Saved New York in the 1960s (Book)
The Con Men: Hustling in New York City (Book)

items.title: New York City’s High School Graduation Rate Tops 70%
items.abstract: The announcement, which also noted that just over 78 percent of state students earned a diploma, came as state officials met to consider changes in graduation requirements.

items.title: Mexico City as the Director of ‘Roma’ Remembers It (and Hears It)
items.abstract: Alfonso Cuarón revisits the sights and sounds of the neighborhood that inspired his critically acclaimed film.

items.title: How Paparazzi Dogs and Rabbitgirl Conquered New York City Streets
items.abstract: Going around the traditional gatekeepers, Gillie and Marc Schattner of Australia have become the city’s most prolific creators of public art.

items.title: How Cities Make Money by Fining the Poor
items.abstract: In many parts of America, like Corinth, Miss., judges are locking up defendants who can’t pay — sometimes for months at a time.

items.title: N.Y. Today: When Schools Are Designed for Black Children
items.abstract: Afrocentric schools tend to have higher graduation rates and test scores. Also, what President Trump and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez have in common.

items.title: What if Cities Are No Longer the Land of Opportunity for Low-Skilled Workers?
items.abstract: Dense cities have long promised higher wages, but now that is primarily true for workers with more education, a new analysis finds.

items.title: Eric Adams Takes Office as New York City’s 110th Mayor at a Perilous Moment
items.abstract: Eric Adams, the city’s second Black mayor, faces difficult decisions over how to lead New York City through the next wave of the pandemic.

items.title: As Omicron Infects Workers, Subway Service Suffers
items.abstract: With coronavirus cases surging in New York, about 21 percent of subway operators and conductors were absent this week, causing suspensions on three lines and changed schedules on others.

items.title: Party for Hong Kong’s Elite Angers a City Under Covid Controls
items.abstract: Just as new restrictions were being imposed, top politicians were found to have attended a large gathering where at least one person had Covid.

items.title: The fire was the deadliest in New York City since 1990.
items.abstract: An arson at the Happy Land Social Club killed 87 people more than 30 years ago.

items.title: A Rising Designer Brings Hip-Hop to Homeware
items.abstract: Sean Brown is the creative force behind Curves, a home décor brand inspired by African American pop culture. “I always aim to celebrate Blackness,” he said.
